title-group.article-title: Diploid origins, adaptation to polyploidy, and the beginning of rediploidization in allotetraploid Arabidopsis suecica

abstract.p: Polyploidization or whole-genome duplication (WGD), followed by genome downsizing is a recurring evolutionary cycle with a significant impact on genome structure. Polyploidy originates from a cell cycle error and in species without a dedicated germline, mitotic as well as meiotic errors can be stably inherited. After the origin, polyploids face immediate challenges, particularly the need to adapt meiotic machinery to prevent improper chromosome pairing and segregation, such as multivalent formation. Over evolutionary timescales, surviving polyploids undergo rediploidization, reorganizing their genomes back to a diploid state. This study focuses on the evolution of a young allotetraploid Arabidopsis suecica, a hybrid species derived from A. thaliana and A. arenosa. Our genomic analyses reveal that A. suecica originated from diploid A. arenosa, contrary to earlier suggestions of a tetraploid origin, indicating that WGD in A. suecica likely occurred somatically rather than being inherited via unreduced gametes. Ecological niche modeling traces the geographic origin of A. suecica to the southeastern edge of the European glacier during the last ice age. We explore how A. suecica adapted to allopolyploidy from diploid ancestors and find evidence of positive selection on meiotic cell cycle genes in the A. arenosa sub-genome. Several of these genes overlap with those involved in autopolyploid adaptation in A. arenosa, but have distinct haplotypes. We also show that purifying selection is relaxed in A. suecica, however, functional compensation between homeologous gene pairs persists, with fewer gene pairs than expected having loss-of-function mutations in both copies. This is consistent with early signs of rediploidization just after ~16K years since the origin of A. suecica. Our study covers three key aspects of the evolution of allopolyploid A. suecica: origin, meiotic adaptation, and the beginning of rediploidization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cycles of polyploidy, or recurrent whole genome duplications (WGDs), have profoundly shaped the genomes of most eukaryotes[1–3]. Particularly common in plants, allopolyploidy, the combination of WGD with interspecific hybridization, is associated with agricultural traits of interest[4,5] as well as tolerance to harsher climates[6]. Notably, key crops like wheat, cotton, Brassica, strawberry, peanut, tobacco, to name a few, are all allopolyploids[7–13]. The importance of allopolyploids requires an understanding of the complex series of events that lead to their origin and establishment, in addition to how their genomes are stabilized and restructured over long evolutionary time[14].

The origin of allopolyploids involves hybridization and WGD, and the timing of WGD—whether it occurs before or after hybridization—may significantly impact how the genome eventually stabilizes. For example, when WGD occurs after hybridization, as in Primula kewensis[15], Capsella bursa-pastoris[16] and in F1 hybrids such as those between Mimulus nelsoni and M. lewisii[17] and between A. thaliana and A. lyrata[18], the resulting neo-allopolyploid must adapt de novo to the challenges of orchestrating divergent genomes to perform basic cellular tasks. However, if WGD happens before hybridization via unreduced (2n) gametes, autopolyploid ancestors that are a natural source of 2n gametes may ease the transition to genome stability by providing alleles that are pre-adapted to the challenges of polyploidy.

One of the main challenges of polyploidy is the stabilization of meiosis, as the formation of multivalents can lead to a failure of proper chromosomal segregation[19,20]. Sub-genomic divergence helps mitigate the challenges of chromosome pairing and the risk of homeologous recombination[21–23], but it does not eliminate it entirely[19,20]. For instance, in A. suecica, with an estimated sub-genome divergence of 11.6%[24] recombination between sub-genomes and genome errors still frequently occur in the early generations of synthetic A. suecica[24–26], highlighting that sub-genome divergence is insufficient to prevent meiotic errors on its own. Autotetraploids also evolve to stabilize meiosis and avoid multivalent formation by redistributing and reducing the amount of crossovers per chromosome. This is a polygenic adaptation described in several species, and involves several genes related to the synaptonemal complex[27–29] but the extent to which these adaptations can benefit genome stabilization in neo-allopolyploids is unknown. Stable allotetraploids do appear to have evolved genetic control of sub-genome specific recombination. Notable examples include Ph1 (ZIP4)[30] and Ph2 (MSH7-3D)[31] loci in allohexaploid wheat, the PrBn locus in Brassica napus[32] and BYS in natural A. suecica[33], all of which suppress homeologous recombination. On a transcriptional level, meiotic-related genes were also shown to be up-regulated on the A. suecica A. thaliana sub-genome[24].

Ancient WGDs in the ancestry of most diploids suggest that current polyploids will eventually return to a diploid-like state through a process known as rediploidization[34]. Rediploidization dramatically restructures polyploid genomes after WGD[35–40], as seen in ancient allopolyploids like maize[41] and current allopolyploids like broomcorn millet[42], and has contributed to distinct morphotypes in Brassica[43]. During rediploidization, relaxed purifying selection in allopolyploids allows mutations to accumulate in redundant gene copies, with functional homeologs compensating for non-functional homeologs, potentially marking the early stages of genome restructuring and downsizing, as observed in Brachypodium hybridum[44]. Additionally, genome restructuring can favor faster fractionation (gene loss) in one sub-genome over another[41,45], possibly due to differences in transposable elements and inherited expression dominance[46]. However, genome dominance is notably absent in several natural allopolyploids[24,42,44,47]. Gene function may also affect fractionation rates, with previous studies showing that genes related to genome integrity and organelle function revert to single copies faster than those involved in signaling, transport, and metabolism, likely due to gene dosage constraints[48].

The allotetraploid A. suecica, a hybrid between A. thaliana and A. arenosa, is an excellent model for studying the cycle of allopolyploid evolution: origin, establishment, and the beginning of rediploidization. Initially, it was hypothesized that A. suecica originated from the fusion of an unreduced egg from diploid A. thaliana with a 2n sperm from tetraploid A. arenosa[49]. However, recent evidence from sequence similarity of meiotic genes points to a diploid A. arenosa parent[50]. Knowing which cytotype contributed to the origin of A. suecica will help our understanding of the genetic basis underlying the evolution of a stable allotetraploid genome in natural A. suecica[24]. We use the recent genome assembly of A. suecica[24] and expanded sequence data from both parental lineages, including the full diversity of A. arenosa cytotypes[24,36,51–53] to reconstruct the evolutionary history of A. suecica and predict the parental cytotypes. To explore how A. suecica adapted to the allopolyploid cell state, we compare its sub-genomes with the defined parental lineages from our reconstruction and identify genes under selection. We notice an overlap between genes under selection in allotetraploid A. suecica and autotetraploid A. arenosa and explore if the haplotypes under selection are shared or independently evolved. Finally, we investigate whether A. suecica, an allotetraploid formed around 16 Kya, shows early signs of rediploidization. Specifically, we analyzed the distribution of inherited and de novo loss-of-function (LoF) mutations across its sub-genomes to see if they are negatively correlated. In other words, when one homeolog (e.g., the A. thaliana gene copy) has a damaging mutation, does the other (e.g., the A. arenosa gene copy) remain intact and functional? Such functional compensation would indicate the onset of rediploidization, and potentially reveal whether there is a non-random progression in this final stage of the polyploidization cycle.

sec.title: Genetic origins of A. suecica
sec.p: To reconstruct the evolutionary history of allotetraploid A. suecica, we first aimed to identify the closest parental accessions, using available data from the parental species, A. thaliana and A. arenosa, covering their vast geographic range. We mapped 970 A. thaliana accessions[53] and 163 A. arenosa individuals (93 tetraploids and 70 diploids), representing spatially close lineages of both diploid and autotetraploid cytotypes[36,51,54], to the A. thaliana and A. arenosa sub-genomes of A. suecica[24]. Genomic positions were conservatively filtered to ensure reliable variant calling (see Materials and Methods). In summary, callable sites included ~62% (73,813,230) of the A. thaliana sub-genome and ~34% (47,950,105) of the A. arenosa sub-genome, with 6,125,591 biallelic SNPs in A. thaliana and 9,664,305 in A. arenosa. Throughout this study, results generated for the sub-genomes of A. suecica are compared with corresponding data from the parental species, A. thaliana and A. arenosa.

Previously, it was shown that the closest A. thaliana accessions to A. suecica are found in Central Eurasia[49]. Here, eliminating the possibility of a reference bias artifact, we calculated median pairwise diversity (π) for each A. thaliana accession to our 16 A. suecica natural accessions and confirmed that result (Figure 1A).

To identify the A. arenosa individuals most closely related to A. suecica and to determine their cytotype (diploid or tetraploid), we expanded the previously released A. arenosa dataset[36,54]. We sequenced five additional autotetraploid A. arenosa individuals sampled from herbarium specimens collected in the southern Urals, representing the easternmost populations and those geographically closest to the parental A. thaliana accessions. The ploidy of most of the A. arenosa individuals was previously determined using flow cytometry[36,54]. For the additional five herbarium individuals, ploidy was inferred using the software nQuire[55] and counting the number of different S-alleles (see Materials and Methods). The combination of these two methods has been used previously to determine ploidy in A. lyrata[56]. We conducted a network analysis based on genetic distances (Nei’s D[57]) that are suitable for mixed-ploidy datasets[58] (Figure 1B). We also calculated the median pairwise nucleotide diversity (π) for each A. arenosa individual against our 16 A. suecica natural accessions and placed it on a geographical map (Figure 1C). Our results indicate that diploid A. arenosa from southern Baltic sea coast[59] is genetically the closest to A. suecica, and certainly closer than any autotetraploid A. arenosa, including both the current sympatric tetraploid Ruderal lineage growing in Fennoscandia[36] and tetraploid populations from the southern Urals, i.e. the geographic region closest to putative ancestral A. thaliana lineage (Figure 1A). A full list of A. thaliana and A. arenosa accessions and their π values to A. suecica is available in Supplementary File 1. The vast majority of the SNPs (>99%) in A. suecica are shared with A. arenosa and A. thaliana, such ubiquitous SNP sharing supports the claim that multiple individuals of A. arenosa and A. thaliana contributed to the origin of A. suecica[49] (Supplementary Figure 1).

Altogether our results suggest a diploid rather than tetraploid origin for the A. arenosa sub-genome within A. suecica. This is in agreement with data showing that meiotic genes on A. arenosa sub-genome of A. suecica are diploid-like rather than tetraploid-like [50]. And it supports the original hypothesis by Hylander in 1957[60] that A. suecica originated from hybridization between diploid A. thaliana and diploid A. arenosa, with autotetraploid A. arenosa later spreading across Fennoscandia, while the diploids remain mostly restricted to southeastern Europe and isolated Baltic areas[59].

sec.title: Geographic origins of A. suecica
sec.p: The origin of A. suecica is estimated to be around 16K years ago[49], when Fennoscandia, where A. suecica is currently distributed [50], was sheathed in ice. The genetically closest A. thaliana accessions to A. suecica are located in Central Eurasia (Figure 1C) and the closest A. arenosa individuals are located in the Southern Baltics (Figure 1B) To clarify the geographic origin of A. suecica, we conducted a niche-modeling analysis to compare the current distribution with the likely geographic range of A. suecica at the time of origin.

We used the occurrence data for A. suecica and corresponding climatic variables to predict the potential distribution of the species across Eurasia (see Methods). We included all of Eurasia to fully capture the geographic distribution of both parental species. The model showed that the present climate niche aligns well with the current distribution of A. suecica, which is restricted to Fennoscandia (Figure 1C, green layer).

Next, we projected the current niche of A. suecica onto the climate of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), the estimated time of the origin for A. suecica[49], assuming that the niche remained similar. The projection resulted in a very narrow distribution following the edge of the ice sheet (Figure 1D, orange layer), which could be suitable for A. suecica. This projected niche partially overlaps with the current distribution of the diploid A. arenosa that is genetically closest to A. suecica, near the southern Baltic Sea coast (Figure 1C, red circles). While the location of the genetically closest A. thaliana accessions is far from the Baltics (Figure 1C, red circles), several A. thaliana accessions, included in the top 5% of the genetically closest to A. suecica, are located relatively near the southern Baltic region (Figure 1D, light brown circles, Figure 1A red circles).

Based on these findings we suggest that the likely geographic origin for A. suecica was near the southern Baltic coast during the last ice age, after which A. suecica migrated to Fennoscandia. The movement of A. thaliana eastwards is also consistent with the demographic post-glacial history of the species[61].

sec.title: Genomic adaptation to allopolyploidy in A. suecica
sec.p: Given that the genetically closest parents of A. suecica were diploids, A. suecica could not inherit any of the potentially pre-adaptive meiotic alleles from autotetraploid A. arenosa. Previously, we reported that meiosis-related genes on the A. thaliana sub-genome of A. suecica are up-regulated compared to parental transcriptional levels[24]. However, in the same study, we did not observe significant upregulation of meiosis-related genes on the A. arenosa sub-genome. Notably, the latter transcriptional comparison was made against tetraploid A. arenosa, the previously assumed parent of A. suecica, whereas we now establish here that diploid A. arenosa is closer. Therefore, to uncover how A. suecica adapted to allopolyploidy from diploid ancestry, we searched for signatures of selection on genes, performing McDonald-Kreitman test between A. suecica and the identified closest progenitors (see Methods). Due to very low genetic diversity within A. suecica, in our gene selection scans we prioritized genes with higher non-synonymous than synonymous divergence and an absence of non-synonymous polymorphisms in A. suecica.

We identified signatures of selection on 35 genes in A. thaliana and 585 genes in the A. arenosa sub-genomes of A. suecica (Supplementary File 2). Due to the low number of founders contributing to the origin of A. suecica[49], large parts of the genome, depleted of genetic diversity, are hard to distinguish from selection sweeps. However, the genes we identified with signatures of selection are also located outside of low-diversity regions (Supplementary Figure 2) and importantly are associated with specific gene ontology (GO) terms (Figures 2A and Supplementary File 2). This suggests that the observed selection signatures likely reflect genomic adaptations in A. suecica.

Genes under selection in the A. thaliana subgenome of A. suecica are enriched for several GO terms, notably including polar nucleus fusion (GO:0010197) and positive regulation of DNA endoreduplication (GO:0032877) (Figure 3A). In the A. arenosa subgenome, enrichment for polar nucleus fusion (GO:0010197) also appears, but involves different genes. Signatures of selection on the A. arenosa subgenome reveals GO terms enriched for mitotic cohesin loading (GO:0061780), suggesting genetic adaptations in A. suecica for chromosome cohesion during cell division—a key factor for genomic stability in polyploids[28]. Among the cohesin-related genes, SISTER CHROMATID COHESION2 (SCC2) encodes adherin, a protein essential for cohesin loading onto chromosomes[62]. We also find enrichment for the meiotic cell cycle (GO:0051321), suggesting genetic adaptations in A. suecica for basic meiotic cell functions (Figure 3A). Genes identified as under selection on the A. thaliana sub-genome in our selection scans here, do not overlap with the transcriptionally upregulated meiosis-related genes reported in our previous study[24].

In the A. arenosa subgenome of A. suecica, SCC2, along with ATRANGAP1, UBIQUITIN PROTEIN LIGASE 4, FRAGILE FIBER 1, and CYCD5, are meiotic genes identified in our selection scan and implicated in polyploid adaptation[27][54].The limited overlap between selected genes in A. suecica and tetraploid A. arenosa, likely reflects the complexity of polyploid adaptation. To investigate whether the modest overlap was due to shared alleles or independent evolution, we performed phylogenetic analyses.

The analyses revealed no shared haplotypes between A. suecica and autotetraploid A. arenosa. Instead, A. suecica consistently clustered with diploid A. arenosa for the five genes examined (e.g., SCC2 in Figure 3B; Supplementary Figure 3). Notably, amino acid variants distinguishing A. suecica from diploid A. arenosa were absent in both tetraploid A. arenosa and the outgroup A. thaliana, suggesting that these polymorphisms arose independently in A. suecica (e.g., SCC2 variants, Figure 3C). We did not observe fixed amino acid differences between diploid and tetraploid A. arenosa in SCC2. This gene, along with other proteins involved in sister chromatid cohesion, has been shown to be under selection in specific diploid and tetraploid lineages of A. arenosa [63][64], emphasizing that the specific populations analyzed in diploid-tetraploid A. arenosa selection scans can influence which genes appear under selection. In our comparison with A. suecica, we included all available diploid lineages. Furthermore, selection scans comparing A. suecica to both diploid and tetraploid A. arenosa consistently identified the same meiotic genes as under selection in A. suecica (Supplementary File 2). This consistency highlights the potential importance of these genes in the adaptation of A. suecica.

sec.title: Early signs of rediploidization in A. suecica
sec.p: Polyploid organisms have a substantial amount of genetic redundancy, which can lead to relaxed purifying selection. This pattern of relaxed selection has been observed in autopolyploid A. arenosa[38] and allopolyploid A. kamchatica[65]. We examined A. suecica for similar signs of relaxed purifying selection and the potential implications this has for the early stages of rediploidization.

Analyzing over 3.5 million SNPs in the A. arenosa sub-genome and 1.2 million SNPs in the A. thaliana sub-genome, we found that both sub-genomes in A. suecica are evolving under purifying selection, however purifying selection appears more relaxed in A. suecica compared to the parental species (Figure 3A). This relaxation in selection pressure likely represents the early stages of rediploidization. During this phase reduced selective constraints following polyploidization enables mutational robustness between the sub-genomes, since a LoF mutation in one sub-genome can be compensated by its homeolog on the alternate sub-genome.

To investigate the compensatory relationship between homeologs we identified 414 homeologous gene pairs with at least one gene carrying a LoF mutation. We observe a slight bias towards A. arenosa homeologs (269 vs 142). However, the majority of the LoF mutations are also segregating in the parental species and, therefore, are most probably inherited rather than evolved de novo after hybridization (Figure 3B). The distribution of de novo LoF mutations (mutations appearing after the allotetraploidization) in homeologous gene pairs was more balanced (49 in A. arenosa, 62 in A. thaliana), suggesting no sub-genome bias in the post-polyploidisation distribution of LoF mutations (Figure 3B). To investigate if these LoF homeologs overlap with genes identified in our selection scans, we compared the genes involved. However, we find little overlap between the gene lists (Supplementary Figure 4), indicating that a LoF occurring on one homeolog is not driving the signals of positive selection we observed.

We next asked if the distribution of LoF mutations between homeologs can be explained by selection acting to preserve at least one functional copy. By comparing the observed LoF distribution between homeolog pairs with randomly paired homeologs, we found significantly fewer cases in A. suecica where both homeologs carry LoF mutations than expected (Figure 3C and D, p < 0.05). This indicates that A. suecica tends to retain at least one functional homeolog, despite an overall relaxed selection pressure—a pattern also supported by in-silico simulations that showed dual LoF mutations occur less frequently in A. suecica than expected from random combinations of A. thaliana and A. arenosa genomes (Figure 3C and D, p < 0.05). These results align with the hypothesis that early stages of rediploidization in A. suecica involves selective pressures that favor maintaining at least one intact homeolog, helping to preserve essential gene functions. Notably, which homeolog remains functional is not biased toward one sub-genome.

Finally, we assessed whether dosage constraints on single-copy genes impact homeolog retention. If dosage constraints were at play, genes that evolve towards single-copy levels[48] would be overrepresented in our dataset, and LoF SNPs would show higher population frequencies in single-copy genes in A. suecica when compared to genes that exist as multi-copies. However, we observed no significant enrichment of single-copy genes among homeologs carrying a LoF mutation, nor do we see that LoF mutations within single copy genes exist at higher population frequencies than LoF mutations within multi-copy genes in A. suecica (Supplementary Figure 5). This suggests that dosage constraints are not a major driver of homeolog rediploidization at this stage of the genome fractionation process.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A. suecica is a relatively young allopolyploid species that originated from the hybridization of A. thaliana and A. arenosa. Using population-level DNA sequencing for all three species, we revisited the genetic origins of A. suecica to understand the nature of WGD leading to the formation of the allopolyploid species and if the ancestry shaped adaptation to allopolyploidy.

Leveraging the recent genome assembly of A. suecica[24], we identified the genetically closest A. thaliana and A. arenosa individuals to A. suecica. Our analysis also supports the conclusion that A. suecica had multiple origins from multiple hybridizations between A. thaliana and A. arenosa[49]. For the A. thaliana sub-genome, our findings align with previous reports[49], and by using the A. suecica genome for SNP calling, we minimized reference bias. Importantly, we find that the A. arenosa individuals closest to A. suecica are diploid, not tetraploid, a key insight into the origin of A. suecica. Given that both parents were diploid, we propose that WGD in A. suecica occurred via somatic genome doubling post-hybridization rather than the fusion of unreduced gametes that were produced independently during meiosis in the parents. Similarly, another allotetraploid in the Arabidopsis genus, A. kamchatica, a hybrid between A. lyrata and A. halleri, is genetically more closely related to diploid rather than autotetraploid A. lyrata[56,66]. This suggests that WGD occurring via somatic doubling in a diploid hybrid could be a common mechanism of allopolyploid formation.

Based on the revised ancestry, we could identify selection signatures on multiple genes in A. suecica, which showed overrepresentation in particular categories (Figure 2). It seems that polar nucleus fusion may play a critical role in reproductive success and endosperm development in polyploids. Notably, in equal ploidy crosses made in the lab between A. thaliana and A. arenosa, ~95% of the seeds are aborted, and one of the main characteristics of the hybrid seed failure is endosperm overgrowth[67]. The role of endoreduplication in polyploid adaptation remains less clear; while endoreduplication may increase cell size and enhance cellular function, its impact on polyploid fitness is uncertain. However, a significant reduction in endoreduplication frequency has been observed in natural A. arenosa autopolyploids[68] and synthetic A. thaliana autopolyploids[69], hinting at a possible cellular trade-off between polyploidization and endoreduplication. We also found that genes under selection in A. suecica are involved in meiosis, which reinforces the idea that divergence of the subgenomes alone can not guarantee the faithful disomic inheritance, and meiotic adaptation is still required. While meiotic genes were previously found to be upregulated on the A. thaliana subgenome of A. suecica by us[24], our selection scans of this sub-genome did not identify GO terms related to meiosis. This suggests that adaptation to polyploidy likely also involves regulatory changes rather than solely changes to the protein of a gene. Future studies that will also use the correct A. arenosa diploid parent will be crucial to disentangle the contributions of cis-regulatory changes versus protein-level changes for adaptation to polyploidization.

Our haplotype analysis of genes in the A. arenosa sub-genome of A. suecica—overlapping with genes identified in previous selection scans between autopolyploid and diploid A. arenosa[27][54]—suggests that adaptation to allopolyploidy in A. suecica involved many of the same genes, but with distinct, independent alleles. Additionally, amino acid changes in A. suecica differ from those both tetraploid from diploid A. arenosa, indicating independent evolution in A. suecica.

The limited contribution of autopolyploids to the origin of allopolyploids raises questions about their suitability as allopolyploid parents. Despite harboring alleles pre-adapted to polyploidy, we propose that autopolyploids may be constrained in two key ways. First, autopolyploids with four homologous chromosome copies can accumulate deleterious mutations due to relaxed purifying selection[38,70]. When a 2n gamete from an autopolyploid contributes to an allopolyploid, these mutations may become exposed and, if not fully compensated by a homeolog, could lead to reduced fitness and increased extinction risk. Second, autopolyploids like A. arenosa exhibit altered meiotic crossover patterns[71]. Whether these altered crossover patterns are beneficial or reversible or could be disruptive for homeolog segregation in allopolyploids remains unknown, but it may further reduce their viability as allopolyploid parents.

We find evidence of relaxed purifying selection in A. suecica, consistent with the idea that polyploidy confers increased mutational robustness through genetic redundancy. Previous studies have shown that diploid A. thaliana is more sensitive to mutagenesis than both natural and synthetic A. suecica[37], supporting the claim that A. suecica has enhanced mutational robustness compared to its diploid parents.

We observed bias in A. suecica toward LoF mutations in the A. arenosa sub-genome, however, most of these LoF mutations also segregate in A. arenosa and are most probably inherited. This is likely due to the high genetic diversity and outcrossing nature of A. arenosa, which allows it to better mask deleterious mutations compared to the highly homozygous and predominantly selfing A. thaliana. De novo LoF mutations did not show subgenome bias, consistent with our previous study, showing absence of subgenome dominance on the transcription level[24].

Our analysis of LoF mutations in A. suecica also reveals a robust gene compensatory mechanism, where the retention of at least one functional homeolog mitigates the impact of LoF mutations. Importantly when a LoF mutation occurs in one copy, the intact homeolog is effectively reverted back to a diploid-like state and will likely remain refractory throughout the genome downsizing processes, in order to maintain the gene function. In agreement, studies in yeast have shown that while additional gene copies do enhance mutational robustness, they are prone to rapid inactivation by LoF mutations rather than gradual subfunctionalization between duplicate genes[72].

We observe no bias toward one sub-genome accumulating more de novo LoF mutations since alloploidization, nor any overrepresentation for dosage-sensitive single-copy genes in homeologs that have been functionally rediploidized. These findings suggest that early stages of rediploidization may be primarily shaped by the random distribution of mutations across sub-genomes, with selection acting post-mutation to retain essential gene functions. As a result, A. suecica exhibits mutational robustness and maintains gene function as the genome gradually evolves back toward a diploid state—a process that will unfold over many generations.

sec.title: DNA extraction of herbarium samples and sequencing
sec.p: Herbarium samples were obtained from Moscow University Herbarium[73]. Extraction of DNA from herbarium samples of five A. arenosa and one A. suecica accession was carried out under a PCR workstation equipped with UV sterilization lights. The workstation, tubes and equipment were UV-sterilized before beginning the extraction. Herbarium samples were weighed and photographed. The material was then crushed using a sterile plastic pestle in a 2ml tube and then weighed again. PTB buffer was added and the material was kept at 37°C overnight on continuous rotation. We extracted the DNA following the protocol of[74]. Libraries were sequenced in 50-bp paired-end mode on Illumina HiSeq 2000 Analyzers at the Vienna BioCenter Core Facilities (VBCF).

sec.title: Read mapping and SNP calling
sec.p: For A. thaliana accessions, 970 accessions of A. thaliana were used from the 1,001 genomes dataset[53], these accessions had a read length greater than 60bp and greater than 8X coverage. In addition to the herbarium samples aforementioned, we used 15 previously published A. suecica accessions[49]. For A. arenosa we used 158 previously published individuals[36,75] in addition to the 5 herbarium A. arenosa individuals from (giving a total of 163 A. arenosa individuals). The A. arenosa individuals used had a minimum of 5X coverage. A complete list of the A. thaliana and A. suecica accessions and the A. arenosa individuals used in this study is available as Supplementary File 1.

We mapped illumina paired-end short reads for the 16 A. suecica accessions, 970 A. thaliana accessions and 163 A. arenosa individuals to a chromosome-level genome assembly of A. suecica[24] using the BWA-MEM algorithm with an increased penalty for unpaired reads set to 15[76] (version 0.7.17). The sub-genomes of the A. suecica accessions were treated separately after partitioning the mapped short reads. The A. thaliana accessions and A. arenosa individuals were mapped to the A. thaliana and A. arenosa sub-genome, respectively. PCR duplicates were removed using the Samtools[77] (version 1.10) rmdup function and SNPS were called using Genome Analysis Toolkit[78] (GATK version 3.8) using the HaplotypeCaller function. Generated gVCFs were combined into a single merged VCF using the combineGVCFs and GenotypeGVCFs functions.

sec.title: Variant filtration
sec.p: We removed multi-allelic sites and indels from our analysis and focused on bi-alleic SNPs. Bi-allelic SNPs were filtered to remove repetitive regions in the A. suecica sub-genomes (TEs sequences, centromere repeats, simple repeats and rDNA repeats). SNPs and non-variant sites were removed if the site was less than -0.5x log median coverage or greater than 0.5x log median coverage.

Heterozygous SNPs in A. thaliana have previously been shown to often result from segregating gene duplications rather than being residual heterozygosity from outcrossing[79]. To avoid SNP-calling errors from segregating gene duplications in our VCF, we removed heterozygous SNPs that were present in A. thaliana and A. suecica at a population frequency greater than 5%, since both are highly selfing species. As A. arenosa is an obligate outcrossing species, to avoid segregating duplicates we removed heterozygous SNPs that were heterozygous in more than 90% of the individuals in the A. arenosa populations we examined. We allowed for 10% missing sites in the A. arenosa VCF. We allowed for 15% missing sites on the A. thaliana VCF.
The final VCFs contained 9,664,305 biallelic SNPs for the A. arenosa sub-genome, and 6,125,591 biallelic SNPs for the A. thaliana sub-genome.

sec.title: Determining the ploidy level of A. arenosa individuals
sec.p: The cytotype of the published A. arenosa individuals ploidy were previously confirmed using FACs[36,75]. nQuire[55] was run on raw fastq files of the 5 herbarium A. arenosa individuals, using the ‘denoised’ function and the ‘Irdmodel’. Ploidy of the sample was determined by taking the ploidy that gave the maximum log-likelihood and lowest delta log-likelihood. Ploidy of the herbarium A. arenosa individuals was further confirmed by counting the number of different S-alleles for each individual with tetraploids having up to four and diploids up to two different S-alleles. The S-alleles were identified as described in[66] using short-read data and NGSGenotyp pipeline[80] with known Arabidopsis SRK sequences as a database.

sec.title: Nucleotide divergence analysis
sec.p: Pairwise nucleotide diversity (π) was calculated using custom scripts (see Code availability) in python. In order to carry out the network based on Nei’s D, we read the VCF into R using the package vcfR[81] and calculated Nei’D using StAMPP[58]. To visualize the network we used the R package tanngle[82] and ggtree[83]. Geographic maps were made using the ggspatial package in R[84].

sec.title: Niche modeling of A. suecica
sec.p: We modeled the niche of A. suecica using the current occurrence records and the selected Bioclim variables to project it onto the climate at LGM. We used workflow described in the ModleR package in R[85] to the entire modeling (set up, evaluation and projection).

We obtained occurrence data of A. suecica from the GBIF database (gbif.org). There are a total of 8451 records available of which we considered records only from preserved specimens having georeferencing data (1772 records). This data was supplemented with the published records[49]. After cleaning the data for duplicates and occurrences in the same pixel 483 clean data points were obtained. Then, species thinning was carried out using the geo_filt function embedded in ModleR. Finally, 197 data points remained after applying the geographic filter of 0.5 km. These occurrence points were considered for further steps. We created 10000 background points using the setup_sdmdata function in the ModleR package.

We obtained 19 bioclim variables from Worldclim climate data (Fick and Hijmans, 2017) at a resolution of 30 arc seconds. We extracted the data for our occurrence points using the R package raster[86]. Multicollinearity was checked for the bioclim variables in order to enhance the model consistency and remove the impact of highly correlated variables. Out of the 19 variables, eight uncorrelated variables (bio3, bio4, bio8, bio9, bio10, bio14, bio15) were then used for further analysis

We used maxent to fit our model, which uses the occurrence data and the corresponding climatic data to predict the probability of distribution of the target species. Twenty-five models were created by partitioning the data into five cross-validation partition types and five runs per partition. We evaluated the performance of these models using the true skill statistic (TSS), which is based on the confusion matrix[87]. The TSS scores span from 0 to 1, where 0 signifies a model performing no better than chance, and 1 denotes a flawless alignment with the observed data. We had set a TSS value greater than 0.7 to prepare the final model. Since all our models showed TSS values >0.9, we considered all 25 models.

The final model was projected onto the past climate (LGM). Further, occurrence points of A. thaliana and A. arenosa were overlaid on the projection to understand the origin and distribution of A. suecica environmentally and spatially.

sec.title: Selection scans
sec.p: To examine polymorphism patterns in genes we first ran SnpEff for annotation, and we used a modified version of the McDonald Kreitman (MK) test in order to find genes showing signatures of selection in A. suecica. We used a modified version of the MK test as A. suecica is evolutionarily young (~16 Kya), meaning if we relied on ratios of divergence to polymorphism in the MK test we would often have division by zero. Therefore we focused instead on genes where nonsynonymous divergence (Dn) exceeded synonymous divergence (Ds), nonsynonymous polymorphisms (Pn) were fewer than synonymous polymorphisms (Ps) and where Pn was zero in A. suecica.

sec.title: Gene ontology (GO) enrichment
sec.p: We used the R package TopGO[88] to perform our GO enrichment analysis, using the ‘weight01’ algorithm to account for the hierarchical structure in GO terms. We kept GO terms with a Fisher test p-value lower than 0.05. We used the gene annotations of A. thaliana one-to-one orthologs of A. suecica genes. Gene annotations for A. thaliana were obtained using the R package biomaRt from Ensembl ‘biomaRt::useMart(biomart = ‘plants_mart’, dataset = ‘athaliana_eg_gene’, host = ‘plants.ensembl.org’).

sec.title: SNP annotation, polarization and homeolog analysis
sec.p: We annotated SNPs using SNPeff (version 5.2). We used 200 of the genetically closest A. thaliana accession to polarize annotated SNPs on the A. arenosa sub-genome. We used 29 individuals of the closest diploid A. arenosa to polarize annotated SNPs on the A. thaliana sub-genome. This resulted in 3,500,145 annotated and polarized SNPs for the A. arenosa sub-genome and 1,205,789 for the A. thaliana sub-genome. 11,812 and 11,983 SNPs, on the A. arenosa and A. thaliana sub-genome respectively, were annotated as predicted LoF polymorphisms that were later used in our homeolog analysis. We excluded SNPs with heterozygosity frequencies exceeding 1% in both A. thaliana and A. suecica to minimize the risk of bias in the LoF mutation analysis, which could be introduced by segregating gene duplicates leading to false signals of heterozygosity. We filtered for homeolog pairs where in A. suecica at least one homeolog in the pair carried a LoF mutation, amounting to 414 genes. In instances where a homeolog carried more than one LoF mutation, we selected the LoF mutation that was at a higher population frequency.

sec.title: Permutation analysis
sec.p: To assess the negative correlation of LoF mutations between the A. thaliana and A. arenosa sub-genomes in A. suecica, we conducted two types of permutation analyses. First, we compared the observed number of LoF mutations in homeolog gene pairs within A. suecica to randomly paired homeologs. From the 414 homeolog gene pairs, where at least one gene in the pair carried a LoF polymorphism, we generated 1,000 permutations of random homeolog pairings. The observed number of homeolog pairs with LoF mutations in both sub-genomes was then compared to the distribution of random pairings to assess whether fewer dual LoF mutations occurred than expected by chance.

Second, we performed a permutation analysis using in-silico A. suecica. We randomly paired A. thaliana and A. arenosa genomes to simulate 1,000 in-silico A. suecica genomes. We used 200 of the genetically closest A. thaliana and 29 of the closest diploid A. arenosa individuals to generate the in-silico A. suecica combinations. The observed dual LoF count in A. suecica was compared to the distribution generated by the in-silico genomes.

sec.title: Analysis of meiotic genes in the A. suecica A. arenosa sub-genome
sec.p: Biallelic SNPs from CDS regions of the genes were used to generate SNP-frequency heatmaps. A.arenosa assemblies from[89] were scaffolded with RagTag[90] on the A.lyrata NT1 genome assembly[66] and annotated with Helixer[91]. A. thaliana protein sequences of target genes were used for protein BLAST[92] against annotated proteins extracted with AGAT[93]. Genes identified by BLAST were aligned with L-INS-i algorithm of MAFFT[94] and trees were constructed with IQTree[95,96] with fast bootstrap option equals 1000. Protein alignments were visualized using snipit[97]

sec.title: Single and multi copy gene analysis
sec.p: Single copy and multi copy genes were obtained from[48] and hypergeometric tests were performed to test for enrichment.

boxed-text.p: Polyploidization, or whole-genome duplication (WGD), drastically reshapes genomes. Most eukaryotic genomes carry the scars of ancient polyploidy events, reflecting cycles of genome doubling followed by downsizing and eventual return to a diploid state. Here, we examine the cycle of polyploidy in Arabidopsis suecica, a hybrid polyploid (i.e. allopolyploid) of A. thaliana and A. arenosa. Starting at the origin, we reveal that the A. arenosa parent of A. suecica was diploid, not tetraploid as previously hypothesized. Given this, the most probable scenario is that two diploid parents formed a sterile diploid hybrid, which partially restored fertility via somatic WGD. Establishment of the new polyploid species requires further restoration of fertility via meiotic adaptation. We find signatures of positive selection in allopolyploid A. suecica acting on meiosis-related genes. Several of the meiosis-related genes overlap with those involved in meiotic adaptation in autotetraploid A. arenosa, but distinct alleles suggest an independent adaptation. Rediploidization concludes the evolutionary cycle of polyploidy, however, pinpointing the beginning of this process is extremely challenging. We show that despite relaxed purifying selection in A. suecica due to genome-wide genetic redundancy, selection acts to preserve one intact functional gene when the alternate gene is damaged in homeologous gene pairs. Within just 16,000 years, A. suecica appears to be undergoing early stages of rediploidization, with some genes already reverting to a single-copy functional state.
